hints.content: Start by understanding the input format. You have a string and an array of substrings. Your goal is to identify which parts of the string match any of the substrings in the array.
Think about how you can check if a substring exists within the main string. You might want to use string methods like `find` or `index` to locate these substrings.
Consider how to track the positions where the substrings appear in the main string. You could create a list of indices that represent the start and end of each matching substring.
When you find a match, remember that you need to wrap it in <b> tags. Plan how you will construct the final string with these tags included.
Think about overlapping substrings. If two substrings overlap in the main string, how will you handle that? You may need to merge ranges or ensure that you don't double-wrap parts of the string.
To keep track of the indices of the bold sections, you could use a boolean array of the same length as the input string. Mark the indices that should be bolded as `true`.
Once you have marked the indices, you can iterate through the original string and construct a new string. Add <b> tags around the sections marked as `true`.
Consider edge cases such as when the input string is empty or when the list of substrings is empty. What should your function return in these cases?
Think about how to handle cases where no substrings match the main string. Ensure your function returns the original string without any modifications in such scenarios.
Finally, implement the logic to iterate through the boolean array and construct the final string. Remember to handle the opening and closing of <b> tags correctly.

questionNotes: The array of substrings can also be empty.
Substrings may overlap; ensure proper handling.
Return the modified string with <b> tags around matching substrings.
